trans-unit.source: Step 2: Upload data into a Machine Learning experiment | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Upload data into a Machine Learning experiment | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Step 2 of the Develop a predictive solution walkthrough: Upload stored public data into Azure Machine Learning Studio.
trans-unit.target: Step 2 of the Develop a predictive solution walkthrough: Upload stored public data into Azure Machine Learning Studio.

trans-unit.source: Walkthrough Step 2: Upload existing data into an Azure Machine Learning experiment
trans-unit.target: Walkthrough Step 2: Upload existing data into an Azure Machine Learning experiment

trans-unit.source: This is the second step of the walkthrough, [Developing a Predictive Solution with Azure ML](machine-learning-walkthrough-develop-predictive-solution.md)
trans-unit.target: This is the second step of the walkthrough, [Developing a Predictive Solution with Azure ML](machine-learning-walkthrough-develop-predictive-solution.md)

trans-unit.source: Create a Machine Learning workspace
trans-unit.target: Create a Machine Learning workspace

trans-unit.source: Upload existing data
trans-unit.target: Upload existing data

trans-unit.source: Create a new experiment
trans-unit.target: Create a new experiment

trans-unit.source: Train and evaluate the models
trans-unit.target: Train and evaluate the models

trans-unit.source: Publish the web service
trans-unit.target: Publish the web service

trans-unit.source: Access the web service
trans-unit.target: Access the web service

trans-unit.source: To develop a predictive model for credit risk, we'll use the "UCI Statlog (German Credit Data) Data Set" from the UCI Machine Learning repository.
trans-unit.target: To develop a predictive model for credit risk, we'll use the "UCI Statlog (German Credit Data) Data Set" from the UCI Machine Learning repository.

trans-unit.source: You can find it here:
trans-unit.target: You can find it here:

trans-unit.source: http://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Statlog+(German+Credit+Data)
trans-unit.target: http://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Statlog+(German+Credit+Data)

trans-unit.source: We'll use the file named **german.data**.
trans-unit.target: We'll use the file named **german.data**.

trans-unit.source: Download this file to your local hard drive.
trans-unit.target: Download this file to your local hard drive.

trans-unit.source: This dataset contains rows of 20 variables for 1000 past applicants for credit.
trans-unit.target: This dataset contains rows of 20 variables for 1000 past applicants for credit.

trans-unit.source: These 20 variables represent the dataset's feature vector, which provides identifying characteristics for each credit applicant.
trans-unit.target: These 20 variables represent the dataset's feature vector, which provides identifying characteristics for each credit applicant.

trans-unit.source: An additional column in each row represents the applicant's credit risk, with 700 applicants identified as a low credit risk and 300 as a high risk.
trans-unit.target: An additional column in each row represents the applicant's credit risk, with 700 applicants identified as a low credit risk and 300 as a high risk.

trans-unit.source: The UCI website provides a description of the attributes of the feature vector, which include financial information, credit history, employment status, and personal information.
trans-unit.target: The UCI website provides a description of the attributes of the feature vector, which include financial information, credit history, employment status, and personal information.

trans-unit.source: For each applicant, a binary rating has been given indicating whether they are a low or high credit risk.
trans-unit.target: For each applicant, a binary rating has been given indicating whether they are a low or high credit risk.

trans-unit.source: We'll use this data to train a predictive analytics model.
trans-unit.target: We'll use this data to train a predictive analytics model.

trans-unit.source: When we're done, our model should be able to accept information for new individuals and predict whether they are a low or high credit risk.
trans-unit.target: When we're done, our model should be able to accept information for new individuals and predict whether they are a low or high credit risk.

trans-unit.source: Here's one interesting twist.
trans-unit.target: Here's one interesting twist.

trans-unit.source: The description of the dataset explains that misclassifying a person as a low credit risk when they are actually a high credit risk is 5 times more costly to the financial institution than misclassifying a low credit risk as high.
trans-unit.target: The description of the dataset explains that misclassifying a person as a low credit risk when they are actually a high credit risk is 5 times more costly to the financial institution than misclassifying a low credit risk as high.

trans-unit.source: One simple way to take this into account in our experiment is by duplicating (5 times) those entries that represent someone with a high credit risk.
trans-unit.target: One simple way to take this into account in our experiment is by duplicating (5 times) those entries that represent someone with a high credit risk.

trans-unit.source: Then, if the model misclassifies a high credit risk as low, it will do that misclassification 5 times, once for each duplicate.
trans-unit.target: Then, if the model misclassifies a high credit risk as low, it will do that misclassification 5 times, once for each duplicate.

trans-unit.source: This will increase the cost of this error in the training results.
trans-unit.target: This will increase the cost of this error in the training results.

trans-unit.source: Convert the dataset format
trans-unit.target: Convert the dataset format

trans-unit.source: The original dataset uses a blank-separated format.
trans-unit.target: The original dataset uses a blank-separated format.

trans-unit.source: Machine Learning Studio works better with a comma-separated value (CSV) file, so we'll convert the dataset by replacing spaces with commas.
trans-unit.target: Machine Learning Studio works better with a comma-separated value (CSV) file, so we'll convert the dataset by replacing spaces with commas.

trans-unit.source: We can do this by using the following Windows PowerShell command:
trans-unit.target: We can do this by using the following Windows PowerShell command:

trans-unit.source: We can also do this by using the Unix sed command:
trans-unit.target: We can also do this by using the Unix sed command:

trans-unit.source: Upload the dataset to Machine Learning Studio
trans-unit.target: Upload the dataset to Machine Learning Studio

trans-unit.source: Once the data has been converted to CSV format, we need to upload it into Machine Learning Studio.
trans-unit.target: Once the data has been converted to CSV format, we need to upload it into Machine Learning Studio.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to Machine Learning Studio ([https://studio.azureml.net](https://studio.azureml.net)) by using the Microsoft account you specified as the owner of the workspace, and click the **Studio** tab at the top.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to Machine Learning Studio ([https://studio.azureml.net](https://studio.azureml.net)) by using the Microsoft account you specified as the owner of the workspace, and click the **Studio** tab at the top.

trans-unit.source: Click **+NEW** at the bottom of the window.
trans-unit.target: Click **+NEW** at the bottom of the window.

trans-unit.source: Select **DATASET**.
trans-unit.target: Select **DATASET**.

trans-unit.source: Select **FROM LOCAL FILE**.
trans-unit.target: Select **FROM LOCAL FILE**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Upload a new dataset** dialog, click **Browse** and find the **german.csv** file you created.
trans-unit.target: In the **Upload a new dataset** dialog, click **Browse** and find the **german.csv** file you created.

trans-unit.source: Enter a name for the dataset.
trans-unit.target: Enter a name for the dataset.

trans-unit.source: For this example, we'll call it "UCI German Credit Card Data".
trans-unit.target: For this example, we'll call it "UCI German Credit Card Data".

trans-unit.source: For data type, select **Generic CSV File With no header (.nh.csv)**.
trans-unit.target: For data type, select **Generic CSV File With no header (.nh.csv)**.

trans-unit.source: Add a description if you’d like.
trans-unit.target: Add a description if you’d like.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Upload the dataset
trans-unit.target: Upload the dataset

trans-unit.source: This uploads the data into a dataset module that we can use in an experiment.
trans-unit.target: This uploads the data into a dataset module that we can use in an experiment.

trans-unit.source: For more information about importing various types of data into an experiment, see [Import your training data into Azure Machine Learning Studio](machine-learning-import-data.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about importing various types of data into an experiment, see [Import your training data into Azure Machine Learning Studio](machine-learning-import-data.md).

trans-unit.source: Next: [Create a new experiment](machine-learning-walkthrough-3-create-new-experiment.md)
trans-unit.target: Next: [Create a new experiment](machine-learning-walkthrough-3-create-new-experiment.md)

trans-unit.target: test
